text:
<@U0821PFKM0V> Good morning! I don't see an updated Schedule for this week but since you just released `0.4.9` for devnet, I also checked mainnet. It should be on `0.4.5` still, but the majority of the mainnet SV's have already upgraded to `0.4.7` :

```{
  "network": "mainnet",
  "sv": {
    "migration_id": 3,
    "version": "0.4.7"
  }
}```
Should we also update mainnet to `0.4.7` ? If not, when according to your planning?

text: Hi, <@U092NF1BX9C>  Version 0.4.8 issues were caused by, and limited to, a single SV node on DevNet using an unusual configuration. None of the SVs on TestNet or MainNet use that configuration, so 0.4.8 is safe to adopt on those networks.

elements.text: Version 0.4.8 issues were caused by, and limited to, a single SV node on DevNet using an unusual configuration. None of the SVs on TestNet or MainNet use that configuration, so 0.4.8 is safe to adopt on those networks.

text: <@U08G1KD2XSB>

When <https://docs.digitalasset.com/operate/3.3/reference/console.html#dars-upload-1|uploading a DAR>, there is the option to specify an `expectedMainPackageId`.

Can I assume from the name of that parameter that if the main package id of the uploaded DAR does not match the provided `expectedMainPackageId`, then the upload fails?

elements.text: , there is the option to specify an

.

Can I assume from the name of that parameter that if the main package id of the uploaded DAR does not match the provided

text: So for example, if (1) I have a DAR file that I am about to upload, and (2) the DAR-file publisher has listed the DAR file’s main package id on their website, then I could (3) include that published main package id in the call to upload the file and (4) gain some additional level of confidence that the DAR file is the intended one?

elements.text: So for example, if (1) I have a DAR file that I am about to upload, and (2) the DAR-file publisher has listed the DAR file’s main package id on their website, then I could (3) include that published main package id in the call to upload the file and (4) gain some additional level of confidence that the DAR file is the intended one?
BTW, I’ve linked to the Canton Console documentation above. For those calling the Admin API, the same parameter is an option:

text:
Yes it will fail with:
```ERROR: 
  Code: FailedPrecondition
  Message: MAIN_PACKAGE_IN_DAR_DOES_NOT_MATCH_EXPECTED```
but yeah gerolf also reiterated what bradley said : MainPackageInDarDoesNotMatchExpected error if there is a mismatch and the upload for the dar in question fails

elements.text: but yeah gerolf also reiterated what bradley said : MainPackageInDarDoesNotMatchExpected error if there is a mismatch and the upload for the dar in question fails

text: I don’t understand the validation that this provides. Presumably whoever is calling this end point can run the same `daml damlc inspect --json` command to get the right input?

elements.text: I don’t understand the validation that this provides. Presumably whoever is calling this end point can run the same
command to get the right input?

text: <@U08H5BYLACX> it’s basically a simple checksum-like validation — I am uploading the DAR i think I am — but instead of checksum of the entire dar contents you are using the main package id as the identifier to match on

elements.text: it’s basically a simple checksum-like validation — I am uploading the DAR i think I am — but instead of checksum of the entire dar contents you are using the main package id as the identifier to match on

text: Hey there, we have an issue getting to the utility frontend page (using docker compose) despite our utility container running smoothly and the DARs uploading successfully. When we get to that link, we just see the Canton Coin Wallet login page that is the web wallet UI basically. Wondering how we can debug this issue and resolve it, because we also have a similar issue with our CNS (Canton Name Service), and I suspect it's the same problem. Is it an nginx issue resolving all our UI's to the web wallet UI or compose.yaml or what is going on?
